Title: Relaxes when you take her in your arms
Body: When you lift her, you feel the baby adjust to the hug and snuggle on your chest

Title: Gets excited when you talk to him
Body: When he hears your voice the baby shows excitement, but you also notice that he slows down his movements, seems to be listening, be present…

Title: Looks at you as you smile and talk to her
Body: When you talk to her, the baby is looking for your face with her eyes

Title: Makes sounds
Body: The baby cries, but also produces sounds

Title: Opens and closes his fist when you gently touch it
Body: When you touch the baby's palm or put something in it, he will close his fist tightly. If you give him your finger he holds it tight.

Title: Moves her arms and legs freely on both sides
Body: When she is free, you may see completely random movements of the baby's arms and legs.

Title: When lying on his tummy, he lifts his head
Body: When you put him lying on his tummy, the baby will try to lift his head to clear the airway.

Title: Makes different sounds when he is happy, upset or hungry
Body: Baby's crying differs when he has certain needs, so based on the sounds he makes it can be recognized whether he is happy, upset or has some other need.

Title: Can comfort herself for a while
Body: The baby soothes herself by sucking her finger or her little hand.

Title: Turns his head towards the sound source and shows that he is listening
Body: If he hears a human voice or some other sound, the baby turns his head towards it. As he listens to the voice he stares at the parent or the person speaking, slowing his movements.

Title: Gurgles, makes sounds
Body: She produces different voices.

Title: Follows the movement of things and people with his eyes
Body: When toys, objects or people move in his field of vision, the baby tries to follow the line of their movement.

Title: Shows boredom or cries if the activity changes
Body: The baby complains by crying if she is left in one position for a long time, or protests if you put her down after holding her in your arms.

Title: Occasionally he keeps his fists open, manipulates them.
Body: The baby still keeps his hands clenched into fists most of the time, but he occasionally opens them and keeps them open for some time. He watches his hands move, brings them to his mouth.

Title: Turns her head to one side, then to the other
Body: The baby makes many different movements of the neck and head.

Title: Makes fine movements with his arms and legs
Body: When he is free you can see a lot of fine random movements of the baby's arms and legs.

Title: When on her tummy, the baby is leaning on her forearms against the mat
Body: When placed in a prone position, the baby may lift her head leaning on her forearms, pushing up against the floor.

Title: Laughs at a human face
Body: Often, easily and spontaneously smiles at people near her.

Title: Carefully observes people's faces
Body: Observes people's faces carefully and in detail, maintains long eye contact.

Title: Shows that she is angry or happy
Body: Has recognizable reactions of satisfaction and dissatisfaction.

Title: Follows with his eyes a toy moving from one side to the other
Body: When objects or persons in the field of view move, he follows the path of movement with his eyes.

Title: Starts babbling
Body: Vocalizes and produces sounds that resemble vowels - a, e, i, o, u

Title: Climbs up and down stairs
Body: Walks up the stairs with support, using alternately one foot and then the other.

Title: Begins to mimic facial movements and expressions, as well as sounds during play
Body: When you address him, your baby tries to repeat the movement or expression. He responds to talk and speech by producing sounds.

Title: Establishes hand-eye coordination
Body: The hand-eye coordination ability increases, for example: your baby looks at an object and tries to reach it.

Title: Copies circles with a pencil, wooden or wax crayon
Body: Copies circles with a pencil, wooden or wax crayon.

Title: Reaches for a toy with one hand, explores it, shakes it and hits it
Body: She reaches for an object and grabs it using the outside of her palm, without using her thumb. She manipulates the object by shaking, hitting or putting it in her mouth.

Title: Puts hands in the mouth
Body: Very often he puts his hands in her mouth. He also explores other objects by putting them in his mouth.

Title: Keeps head upright, without head support
Body: When in a semi-sitting position, she can keep her head balanced and upright.

Title: In the prone position, leans steadily on the forearms and pushes up on the elbows
Body: As she lies on her tummy, she raises her shoulders and head high leaning on her elbows.

Title: Develops a complex play and involves others in it
Body: Likes pretend play, the play is imaginative with a lot of fictional elements. Sometimes it is not certain what is real and what is make-believe.

Title: Sings parts of simple songs
Body: Sings parts of simple songs.

Title: Rolls from the tummy to the back and from the back to the tummy over both sides
Body: She can roll over and turn in any direction (both over the left and over the right side) both from back to tummy and from tummy to back.

Title: Can sit with some support
Body: When he has support or holds onto something, the baby can sit, and for a short time can maintain the sitting position independently.

Title: Can say a sentence of 2 to 3 words
Body: Can compose and say sentences of 2 to 3 words well enough for the family members to understand her.

Title: When held upright, she can bear her weight for a short time by leaning on her feet
Body: When you hold your baby upright above the floor, she leans on the floor or looks like she is bouncing.

Title: Can say own name, age and gender
Body: Can say own name, age and gender

Title: Explores things by putting them in his mouth.
Body: He puts everything he reaches in his mouth, very often he also brings his feet to his mouth.

Title: Reaches for things that are out of reach with one hand, and when she grasps them, she can move them from one hand to another
Body: She is still reaching for objects with one hand, but manipulates by transferring them from one hand to the other using the radial part of the palm, thumb and forefinger while the other fingers remain fixed.

Title: Understands complex words
Body: Understands terms such as "similar" and "different", "easy" and "difficult", "good" and "bad", "small" and "big".

Title: Responds to the sound of the voice by making sounds - by merging vowels: a, e, u...
Body: When someone is addressing him, talking, singing, reading to him…the baby responds.

Title: Loudly expresses dissatisfaction or joy
Body: She cries or protests loudly to express unpleasant feelings, and laughs loudly to express pleasure.

Title: Understands the meaning of words such as "mine, yours, hers", uses prepositions and pronouns
Body: Pronounces words such as "I", "you", "we" and knows the plural forms of some words - "dogs", "cats".

Title: The baby is excited when he realizes that it's time to play
Body: He rejoices, looks happy and enjoys the play and contact, especially with parents and familiar persons.

Title: Follows the instructions that contain two or three orders
Body: Can respond to multiple linked oral requests (“leave the doll and sit on the chair” (“take off your jacket and put on your slippers”).

Title: Shows a wide range of emotions, recognizes emotions in others
Body: Shows anger, fear, guilt, shame, and begins to show empathy, so she recognizes how others feel (for example, she wants to comfort his crying friend with a hug).

Title: Recognizes family members and distinguishes them from strangers. The baby may be afraid of strangers.
Body: Recognizes family members and distinguishes them from strangers. The baby may be afraid of strangers. She is happy to see familiar persons, laughs at them, responds differently to familiar and unfamiliar people.

Title: Likes to play in the company of children
Body: Play is no longer just parallel – side by side, but has more complex elements, imagination and playfulness.

Title: Gets upset when the parent leaves the room and relaxes when the parent returns.
Body: Gets upset when the parent leaves the room and relaxes when the parent returns. He shows signs of anxiety or starts crying when the parent leaves the room. He is happy when a parent or close persons return.

Title: Reacts when she hears own name.
Body: Reacts when she hears own name. She begins to recognize her name when someone calls her.

Title: Finds it easier to separate from parents
Body: Reactions to separation are less intense, she calms down faster, and learns to rely on other adults who are close by when parents leave.

Title: Begins to understand the meaning of the word "no".
Body: Begins to understand the meaning of the word "no".  When he hears the word, he stops the activity and recognizes disapproval.

Title: Babbles, makes syllables and produces many different sounds
Body: Babbles, makes syllables and produces many different sounds. She uses multiple combinations of sounds and pairs different consonants and vowels, tries to repeat or imitate the sounds that adults pronounce.

Title: Can go up and down the stairs
Body: Can go up and down the stairs, with support Is able to climb stairs or go down them with a little help.

Title: Begins to communicate with movements.
Body: Begins to communicate with movements. He communicates non-verbally, pointing to the desired objects with his hand or shaking his head to indicate "no".

Title: Follows the falling object and looks for the hidden object
Body: Follows the falling object and looks for the hidden object. If the object is hidden under a cup or a blanket, the baby tries to discover it. When an object falls or mommy throws it, the baby looks for the thrown object with her eyes.

Title: Can stand on her toes, run, jump, kick the ball
Body: Can stand on her toes, run, jump, kick the ball and throw it over her head.

Title: Uses one hand more than the other
Body: Begins to use one hand more - left or right.

Title: Scribbles independently on paper
Body: He is capable of holding a pencil and making doodles, drawing or copying lines and circles.

Title: Still puts objects in his mouth
Body: Still puts objects in his mouth. The baby explores objects by putting them in his mouth.

Title: Begins to sort and pair things
Body: She can pair, for example, an animal with an animal, a sock with a sock.

Title: Smoothly transfers objects from hand to hand, shakes them.
Body: Smoothly transfers objects from hand to hand, shakes them. She manipulates objects by moving them from left to right hand and vice versa.

Title: Picks up small objects.
Body: Picks up small objects. He picks up small objects using his thumb and forefinger. He still uses the entire surface of his finger, not just fingertips to hold the object.

Title: Uses toys purposefully in games
Body: Can play with toys, knows what they are for and how to use them in play.

Title: Can sit up on her own and sit without support.
Body: Can sit up on her own and sit without support. She independently takes a sitting position. She sits without additional support and assistance.

Title: Lifts himself up to a crawling position. Some children are already crawling.
Body: Lifts himself up to a crawling position. Some children are already crawling. He can get into a crawling position on his own. He moves by crawling whether it`s backwards or forwards.

Title: Play simple “pretend” games
Body: Plays simple “pretend” games, for example – feeds a doll, eats a cake.

Title: Pushes away, tries to stand up.
Body: Pushes away, tries to stand up. She tries to get up holding on to the furniture, but she needs help and support.

Title: Shows shyness and nervousness in communicating with strangers
Body: In the presence of strangers, he shows different behaviour than with the people he knows. He starts being embarrassed of persons he does not know (avoids eye contact, clings to familiar persons).

Title: Parts of the child`s communication are also understood by people who are not with him every day
Body: He begins to pronounce voices more clearly and uses more and more words with meaning, and therefore communication is easier.

Title: Knows animals and its sounds
Body: Associates sound with animals.

Title: Cries when separated from her parents
Body: Shows signs of prominent anxiety immediately after separation from parents.

Title: In communication with people, uses a combination of words and gestures
Body: Utters a sentence with 2 to 4 words, and talks about herself in the third person "Mia wants", "Emma sits".

Title: Has a favourite toy
Body: Prefers a certain toy, looks for it, carries it with her.

Title: Spontaneously seeks to share interests and pleasures with adults
Body: Enjoys reciprocal games, "I give it to you - you give it to me", "I do - you do" and the like.

Title: Understands his name, names of familiar persons, names of objects from his environment, everyday actions and the word "no"
Body: Adequately responds to the call of his name or the word "no".

Title: Repeats syllables, and some children can already say words with the meaning
Body: Produces a lot of different sounds (maaa, baaa, daaad...) and uses some of them as the first recognizable words knowing their meaning (mom, dad…).

Title: Understands a brief instruction or order
Body: Understands when you tell her "bring the ball" or "give it to mom".

Title: Imitates and uses gestures
Body: He can say "pa-pa" for greeting, shakes his head for "no", points to the object he wants.

Title: Understands and follows more than one simple instruction
Body: Can follow one or even more related simple oral requests such as: “Bring a pillow”, “Come sit”, “Throw it in the bin”…

Title: Curiously examines toys: shakes them, bangs, throws, pays attention to details.
Body: Explores objects by banging or pounding one into another (pounding a cup onto a table or a toy on another toy).

Title: Picks small objects with her fingers, feeds with her fingers
Body: Has a better "pincer grasp" - can manipulate very small objects by taking them with her thumb and forefinger.

Title: Puts things in a box and takes them out of it.
Body: Has the ability to manipulate objects more precisely. He can even put small objects in a box or a bottle and take them out.

Title: Plays side by side with other children
Body: Plays independently next to other children, doesn't need to join them but doesn't spoil their game, can start to gradually involve them in the play, for example, by offering them a toy.

Title: Stands up by holding onto to the furniture and starts walking next to the furniture.
Body: She may be able to stand with support or even stand alone for a short time without support. She tries to move by holding on to furniture or holding the hand of an adult.

Title: Imitates the behaviour of adults and older children
Body: Imitates adults and does things she sees from them, for example: pushes a pram, reads a newspaper…

Title: Helps with dressing
Body: Cooperates when you dress him, pushes  his hand through the sleeves and legs through hoses.

Title: Is becoming more and more independent
Body: Sometimes he resists orders, gets angry, wants to control others, quarrels, orders, defends his things.

Title: Can express feelings
Body: Can express and show a variety of feelings: fear, anger, compassion, guilt, joy.

Title: Stands, moves and walks independently.
Body: He can move independently in different directions, at different speeds or combine different movements (to stop moving and wave).

Title: Understands and executes simple orders
Body: Follows simply stated instructions with no demonstration, can perform what is expected of him.

Title: Pronounces words with meaning
Body: She speaks at least one or a few individual words when addressing parents.

Title: Still shows fear of strangers and situations
Body: In contact with a stranger, he reacts with fear, looking for a familiar person or clinging to a parent.

Title: Likes to play pretending games
Body: Plays “pretend games” “Pretend play” appears, she pretends to drink tea, feeds a doll, etc.

Title: Scribbles independently with a pencil or crayons on paper
Body: Likes to use the scribble movement, whether it`s with a pencil on paper, with a hand on sand, with a stick on mud, or water on concrete.

Title: Knows how to use items for everyday use
Body: Demonstrates knowledge of using objects such as spoon, toothbrush, telephone.

Title: Puts one item into another
Body: Puts things in a bowl or a cup and takes them out of it.

Title: In communication, he uses gestures for better mutual understanding
Body: He tries to imitate the gestures that adults make and the words they say. Adequately uses gestures in response to requests (“bye-bye” or “no”).

Title: Looks forward to joint activities
Body: She imitates facial expressions, gestures and some activities of close people, points with her index finger to what interests her or offers things to other people in order to interest them and involve them in the game.

Title: Shows more interests in books
Body: Shows interest in picture books, can turn the pages of a hardcover booklet on his own.

Title: Shows interest in playing with other children and adults
Body: Seeks out others to play with, knows how to get involved in play and learns from other children and adults when playing.

Title: Likes to please others and cooperate
Body: Recognizes others’ feelings; often enjoys sharing with others; able to take turns.

Title: Uses sentences of 4 to 5 words
Body: Puts words together in ways that make sense and communicate her/his ideas.

Title: Understands the meaning of the numbers 2 and 3
Body: If asked, can choose two or three of something (toys, spoons, etc.) or look at a group of things and say there are two or three.

Title: Understands the terms "similar" or “alike” and "different" and can group things in different ways (such as color or size)
Body: For example, the child might talk about animals that have fur and those that have feathers; the child might point out one thing that is different from others in a book (for example, the only boy that is holding a ball).

Title: Knows basic differences between things that are real, pretend or imaginary
Body: Makes up a story about a character that does not exist, or knows animals cannot talk in real life.

Title: Talks about things that happen in her/his life
Body: Can tell about a birthday party that happened last week or describe a trip with the family.

Title: Sings songs or tells stories that have been memorized
Body: Thinks about a story or song heard in the past and tries to remember the words.

Title: Can write some letters of the alphabet or try to copy other images when they are shown to her/him beforehand
Body: Looks at letters or pictures of objects and tries to copy them even though they might not look accurate.

Title: Uses fingers and hands more precisely
Body: Shows more skill in using scissors; builds towers (for example, of 8 or more big blocks).

Title: Plays simple games with rules
Body: Follows simple rules of games, waits for a turn.

Title: Walks, runs, jumps, throws and kicks big and small balls easily and more skillfully
Body: Uses body skillfully (for example, if available—rides scooter or bicycle, roller skates, etc.).

Title: Uses body more skillfully for many activities
Body: Stands on one leg, jumps, swings, climbs. If an opportunity is available, rides a bicycle or scooter and skillfully manipulates a ball using only her/his arms and only her/his legs.

Title: Draws accurate image of human body and simple shapes
Body: Draws human figure with parts visible; can draw a circle, triangle, and other geometric figures.

Title: Speaks in sentences of five or more words; uses words to talk about the future
Body: Puts words together to express her/his ideas; can say what “will” or “may” happen in the future.

Title: Can tell a story or retell part of a story
Body: Independently retells the main ideas in a story or a favorite part of a story, as an adult may suggest.

Title: Can say name and address
Body: If asked, can recite basic information about herself/himself.

Title: Can count to ten and name ten objects without mistakes
Body: Can also say “first, second,” up to 10, count days of week and months.

Title: Names at least four colors correctly
Body: Color recognition includes some colors such as purple and orange (not just red, yellow, blue).

Title: Understands time concepts such as before and after
Body: Explains what happened before and after an event; can put seasons in order (summer after spring, for example).

Title: Can explain how everyday objects are used
Body: Explains how things like a phone or money are used in everyday life.

Title: Chooses to participate in creative activities
Body: Gets involved in activities like singing and dancing, drawing and painting, modeling with clay or other materials and other creative activities.

Title: Uses skills to independently participate in everyday routines and social activities
Body: Can dress and undress independently, uses a spoon and fork, uses the toilet alone and washes hands. Can separate from parents and get involved in independent social activities.

Title: Skillfully participates in varied activities requiring advanced physical skills
Body: Able to stand on one leg, kick a ball precisely, hit a target with a ball etc.

Title: Is able to make complex shapes, letters, and detailed drawings
Body: Can put realistic details in a drawing, makes more complex pictures, uses drawing and painting materials skillfully if has an opportunity.

Title: Speaks in complex sentences
Body: The sentences are more and more complex. For example, the child uses the present, past and future tenses correctly.

Title: Recognizes letters of the alphabet and has some reading skills
Body: Can recognize most letters of the alphabet and can read basic everyday words and syllables such as a shop, a book, ma-ma, da-da etc.

Title: Tells a complete story
Body: The child manages to retell the plot of a certain story completely independently and accurately, correctly arranging the events in chronological order, the event in which he/she participated, or a TV show.

Title: Knows her/his name and surname, age, and home address
Body: He/she knows basic information about himself/herself and can reproduce it on request.

Title: Understands what happens at different times and how time passes
Body: Understands the passage of time, understands what happens in the morning, at noon and in the evening, can plan some activities.

Title: Follows rules of games and sometimes has ideas for new rules
Body: He/she understands the rules that have been set (for example, the Rules of the Game), but occasionally he/she wants to add some new, different ones.

Title: Shows signs of taking responsibility
Body: For example, he/she begins to take care of his/her own things.

Title: Shows understanding of difference between real and pretend or make-believe
Body: He/she only invents stories, events, characters from his/her imagination, artistically presents, describes, and assigns them properties that are not realistic. He/she has fun while doing it, aware that everything is possible in the world of imagination.

Title: Has understanding of other people’s ideas and needs
Body: That is why he/she pays more attention to what others want or suggest and wants to meet them – he/she is more cooperative with friends and in team functioning.
